Author: YanSidorov#2533
Content:
Hey everybody
I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around the "ac_blocktime" configuration. I do understand that we set the desired average time for a block to be mined and it does not necessarily has to be exactly the value configured.
However, while I have ac_blocktime set to 5 (which is supposed to be 5 seconds, I believe), it actually takes my nodes about a minute or so to create a new block. It's been more then few days already and the network had to stabilize at this point (that is if I understand the term correctly)
So I was wondering if I'm missing something here. Does the nodes count have to do anything with the network ability to keep up with the desired blocktime? As I'm currently testing it with a network that consists of only two nodes.
Appreciate any help, thanks!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how fast are your CPU?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: are you mining with one core each?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you probably need to mine with more cores or use faster CPU if you only have 2 nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the idea is to have dozens (or hundreds) of nodes CPU mining, so the time to calculate a block can be short. but 5 seconds might be a bit too fast

Author: Alright#0419
Content: 5 seconds may be too fast for CPU miner in daemon all together

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Would recommend you try a stratum, if that doesn't work well(it should), increase blocktime

Author: YanSidorov#2533
Content:
I see, thanks. Probably the CPU is indeed a bottleneck, it ain't of the top-notch.
@Alright , care to share any articles or docs on what stratum actually is? So far I've managed to find a Knomp GitHub repository and few stratum protocol mentions in Komodo docs, but none of those shed any light.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: stratum protocol is what basically all mining pools use to split shares amongst many miners

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you can use https://github.com/webworker01/knomp/

Author: Alright#0419
Content: why do you need such fast blocktimes?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it's likely to cause issues, would recommend at least 10 seconds

Author: Alright#0419
Content: 5 seconds should work, but you'll have a lot of orphans

Author: Alright#0419
Content: will be a lot more bandwidth than it needs to be because of that

Author: YanSidorov#2533
Content:
It isn't really me who need such a short blocktime. My customers do.
They want to have a transaction processing time like 3-5 seconds while having as least nodes as it's possible (don't even ask me the point of it, there's none üôÇ )
So I was just trying to figure out if it's even possible to achieve

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: use GPU to mine then

Author: gcharang#6833
jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but for 5 seconds txtime for unconstrained tx, having a smallish number of nodes and GPU mining would be the way.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: agreed, but someone asking for 3-5 second blocktime is most likely looking for instant payments

Author: Alright#0419
Content: yes, if you don't expect to have many mining nodes, 5 seconds will be fine with a GPU

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the problem is when you have many mining nodes trying to produce 5 second blocks, you have orphans for basically every block

Author: Alright#0419
Content: doubling(or even more) the bandwidth used

Author: YanSidorov#2533
Content:
I see your point. Thanks, pals!
I'll try looking into stratum and channels deeper.
